content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, MeHg induced neurite degeneration followed by apo- ptosis in differentiating PC12 cells. We showed that the TrkA pathway was an early target of MeHg, and that suppression of the TrkA pathway resulted in neuritic degeneration followed by apoptosis. GM1 ganglio- side and its analog, MCC-257, suppressed MeHg-induced neuronal degeneration and apoptotic cell death through the activation of the TrkA pathway in vitro. The effect of MCC-257 on MeHg-intoxication was confirmed clinically and pathologically in a MeHg-intoxicated rat model. Our results suggest that the TrkA pathway is an early target of MeHg, and that compounds that enhance activation of the TrkA path- way are useful against MeHg-induced neuronal degeneration. content.CoiStatement: It is important that the concentrations used in this work are not far from the US EPA recommended reference concentration in blood cord for Hg (5.8 μg/L; 29 nM), which is considered not to produce appreciable harm. It should be noted that recent studies of several newborn cohorts in Brazil, China, Japan, Spain, and the USA reveal higher mean concentrations of Hg in blood cord: in the range 8–17 μg/L (equivalent to 40–85 nM) (Fok et al., 2007; Oliveira Santos et al., 2007; Sakamoto et al., 2007; Lederman et al., 2008; Ramón et al., 2008). Therefore, the findings of this study may be relevant to human exposure to methylmercury worldwide. It is noteworthy that low nanomolar concentrations of methylmercury have also been found to impair the neuronal differentiating potential of cultured neural stem cells (Tamm et al., 2006). In conclusion, we have found that the cofilin phosphorylation balance is altered in cerebellar granule neurons exposed to low concentrations of methylmercury. This alteration was produced earlier than cytotoxic effects were observed in the cells, suggesting that cofilin might be an early target of methylmercury neurotoxicity. content.Compliance with ethical standards: inhibitor of apolipoprotein B) and lomitapide (MTP inhibitor) are drugs approved for the treatment of familial hyperlipidemia (Rosenson, 2021). Both of these drugs possess a risk of hepatic fat accumulation (France, 2016). Mipomersen is an injectable drug, while lomitapide is orally efficacious. MTP inhibition blocks assembly and secretion of apolipo- proteins leading to accumulation of lipids in liver and may cause fatty liver. In individuals with familial hypercholesterolemia, lomitapide effectively reduces serum lipids, but is associated with elevated liver aminotransferases levels in serum presumably due to hepatic fat accu- mulation and associated hepatocellular injury. This leads to decreased patient compliance to lomitapide therapy (Yoshida, 2017). Selective intestinal inhibitors of MTP like slx-4090 and JTT-130 were previously observed to reduce the side effect of MTP inhibition but were unsuc- cessful in clinical trials. Thyroid hormones especially T3, decrease serum and hepatic lipids and increase ß-oxidation of accumulated fat in the liver (Joharapurkar et al., 2012). Triiodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4) are two hormones produced and released by the thyroid gland. T4 is converted to T3 by deiodinase. T3 is the biologically active that binds to thyroid hormone receptors (TR). T4 must be converted to T3 in order to elicit biological activity. Both would have similar effect, but T3 is more potent than T4 (Abdalla and Bianco, 2014). It also increases the synthesis of bile salt from accumulated lipids. We hypothesized that the lipid lowering actions of thyroid hormone may prove to be complimentary to lomitapide treatment. The Zucker fatty rat, a model of metabolic syndrome, shows hyperlipidemia associated with obesity and insulin resistance (Wong et al., 2016). Treatment with triiodothyronine in combination with lomitapide in Zucker fatty rats caused a decrease in body weight, cholesterol, LDL, and glucose during OGTT which was greater in effect than either lomitapide or T3 treatment alone. This fatty rat model is known to respond to lomitapide treatment (Dhote et al., 2011). Lomitapide caused a reduction in food intake, whereas T3 increased it. However, the combination of T3 with lomita- pide caused profound suppression of body weight gain without a sig- nificant change in food intake. Triiodothyronine treatment improves glucose intolerance in obese rats (Vazquez-Anaya et al., 2017). Lomi- tapide is also reported to improve glucose intolerance in Zucker fatty rats (Dhote et al., 2011). The combination of T3 with lomitapide had an additive effect on glucose tolerance. In this study, lomitapide treatment reduced serum triglyceride levels, though addition of T3 had little additional impact on this effect. Treatment with T3 and lomitapide alone reduced serum total cholesterol and LDL. However, combination treat- ment resulted in greater reduction in total cholesterol and LDL than either T3 or lomitapide treatment alone.

content.CoiStatement: Treatment of mice with a synthetic inhibitor specific to either iNOS or MMPs efficiently attenuates the severity of experimental colitis (Cross and Wilson, 2003; Medina and Radomski, 2006). Similarly, we observed that minocycline blocked expression of both MMP (Fig. 5) and iNOS (Fig. 6), which makes minocycline an attractive alternative for treatment of IBD. Interestingly, minocycline also has protective effects against arthritis and skin diseases such as pyoderma gangrenosum, both of which are extraintestinal manifes- tations associated with patients with IBD (Barrie and Regueiro, 2007). In addition, minocycline has recently been proven to have promising long-term therapeutic effects on rheumatoid arthritis with no obvious side effects (Stone et al., 2003). Given its moderate toxicity and relatively low cost, detailed studies on the mode of action of minocycline treatment and clinical trials using human IBD patients are warranted. In summary, d4T induced a mitochondrial oxidative stress in human hepatocytes and these changes precede cytotoxicity. This was associated with a loss of mtDNA fidelity, altered complex I levels, and elevated lactate production. Mitochondrial oxidative stress links the dec- reased abundance of mtDNA and altered energetics of NRTI toxicity (Fig. 10). Mitochondrial oxidative stress may be a major contributing factor to NRTI-induced toxicity, may be potentiated by other factors that generate mitochondrial oxidative stress such as HIV infection, coinfections, aging, and alcohol use, and may be a target for pharmacological intervention to increase antiviral efficacy. content.CoiStatement: We surmise that our preliminary data clearly demonstrate that the recruitment of key BR regulatory enzymes into mitochondria is an adaptive response to PYR-induced oxidative stress, potentially to protect mitochondria against severe oxidative damage. The placement of a local system to regulate mitochondrial BR homeostasis is perhaps to protect the organelles against ROS generated bymitochondrial respi- ration and from exposure to toxic chemicals. Our future studies aim at further understanding the role of mitochondrial BR regulating enzyme system in cytoprotection and in mitochondria associated diseases. content.Funding: There appear to be no toxicologically meaningful differences between so-called natural and synthetic chemicals. In the body, chemicals are chemicals, and risk of harm is driven by potency and exposure. The natural:synthetic distinction may serve political and funding objectives, but availability of funding appears to have grossly distorted the balance of toxicological research toward synthetic chemicals. Using synthetic pesticide residues in foods as a point of reference, it is apparent that there are far higher levels of natural toxicants in food than of synthetic pesticide residues. Ames (1983) estimated that “… dietary intake of ‘natures pesticides’ is likely to be several grams per day–probably at least 10,000 times higher than the dietary intake of man-made pesticides” (p. 1258). Beier and Nigg (2001) estimated that people might consume 60 ug per day of synthetic pesticides and herbicides, while natural pesticide consumption is about 4.8 to 6 million ug/day. “These numbers result in a natural pesticide potential of 80,000 to 100,000 times that of synthetic chemicals in the diet” (p. 132). Although the exposure estimates of Ames (1983) and Beier and Nigg (2001) contrast natural and synthetic pesticides, the important point is not limited to pesticides. The point is that people are exposed to large amounts of natural toxicants in their daily lives, and the risk implications of these exposures are largely ignored in contemporary toxicology. Essers et al. (1998) recommended that “in light of the small safety margins for many inherent toxicants in plant food, there is a need for more accurate risk assessments of these substances in food. There is very little data on these substances” (p. 170). Essers et al. make several recommendations on how to address food safety, and propose that priorities should driven by the severity of the health risk involved, the degree of human exposure, and the feasibility of conducting a useful study.

content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, our results indicate that the MOA of ETBE hepatotumorigenicity in rats is similar to that of PB except for the acti- vation of PPARs. The mechanisms are related to conspicuous alteration to DNA oxidative base modifications in the nucleus of hepatocytes via generation of oxidative stress due to the activation of CAR, PXR and PPARswith a sequence of eventswhichpresumably lead to regenerative cell proliferation. The MOA of ETBE hepatotumorigenicity in rats is un- likely to be relevant to humans. Discussion Acknowledgments References

We observed that both SSBs and SSBs endonuclease III sites increased with the increasing mRNA expression levels of XRCC1, hOGG1 and XPC, but not with γ-irradiation-specific DNA repair rates. It is therefore difficult to ascribe arising SSBs to the intermediates of DNA repair (as SSBs reflect levels of DNA strand breaks, apurinic/ apyrimidinic sites as well as intermediates in the repair process (Collins, 2009). Among the analyzed confounders the only significant correlation was detected between smoking and XPC expression. This finding is in accordance with a recent study, where XPC mRNA levels induced by ionizing radiation were substantially affected by smoking (Wiebalk et al., 2007). This present study has an advantage of investigating the end- points of styrene genotoxicity in relation with DNA repair capacity and simultaneous measurement of mRNA expression levels in three relevant DNA repair genes. The selection of DNA repair genes of interest was based on our previous studies (Vodicka et al., 2004b, 2007), reporting the links between genotypes in XRCC1, hOGG1, and, partially, XPC and γ-irradiation-specific DNA repair rates. Obtained data may contribute to our understanding of styrene- induced genotoxicity and the response of DNA repair system, assayed for by the determination of mRNA expression levels of XRCC1, hOGG1 and XPC genes, and BER rates. Understanding themolecular responses to genotoxic stress requires further highly-targeted study, aimed mainly at discerning the role of DNA damage sensing, DNA repair pathways (functional tests) and the regulation, function and modification of the relevant proteins/enzymes at the protein level in the cells following the exposure to xenobiotics. Supplementarymaterials related to this article can be found online at doi:10.1016/j.taap.2010.07.027. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, results showed the novel ability of mirtazapine to at- tenuate TAA-induced liver injury in vivo. The anti-fibrotic properties of mirtazapine can be attributed, at least in part, to down-regulating TGF- β1 induced Smads and ERK1/2 signaling pathways and attenuating ox- idative stress. Treatment of liver fibrosis with specific antagonists of 5- HT2A receptor may offer a new therapeutic approach in humans, which needs to be assessed in further studies. A critical next step is to generate a tissue-specific agent that targets 5-HT2A receptor and does not cross the blood-brain-barrier. This should minimize the potential for psychotropic side effects. In summary, this is the first report indicating that exposure of cultured lung cancer cells and non-tumorigenic bronchial epithelial cells to Cr(VI) was able to induce both global and gene-specific changes in histone methylation. These changes affected marks that activate and repress gene expression, leading to DNA hypermethyla- tion in tumor suppressor genes and DNA hypomethylation in other genes that may promote tumorigenesis as well as tumor progression. Thus, further analysis using primary lung epithelial cells will provide more insights into the epigenetic mechanism underlying tumorigeni- city of Cr(VI). A more detailed analysis of genome-wide and gene- specific changes in these active and repressive marks will significantly add to our understanding of chromate cytotoxicity, genotoxicity, and carcinogenicity. With regard to genetic susceptibility, studies to date have shown that the NQO1 C609T polymorphism raises risk of leukemia especially in infants. Polymorphisms in the folate metabolizing pathway may also be involved, showing that folate and perhaps other dietary components are important risk factors. International collaboration is needed to produce large studies so that these associations can be definitively examined in the case-control setting. It is important to have the physical space for these samples as well as an effective labeling and tracking system. Storing these samples in a biorepository has several advantages. Sample utility is maximized in that they can be used in the future as new biomarker tests develop. Student projects become more feasible and costs of future studies are decreased with the elimination of the sample collection stage. A specimen bank is available for future intra-center collaboration and for development of new methods. Also in today’s tight budget environment, biorepositories are providing additional incentives for extramural funding. These results demonstrate that hPT cells can respond to toxicant exposures at the appropriate times and concen- trations by inducing expression of proteins that alter cell fate. Changes in expression of proteins such as Hsp27, p53, and c-Jun implicate the function of multiple signaling pathways. Future studies on the role of these signaling pathways will provide further insight into the regulation of these responses to toxicant exposure and will suggest approaches to ameliorating the toxic effects. content.CoiStatement: The participation of Wnt signaling pathway in cultured LX-2 cells and DEN induced liver fibrosis model was examined in the current study. Prominent protein levels of Wnt5a/b, Wnt3a, GSK-3β and β-catenin in untreated LX-2 cells demonstrated the active participation of Wnt signaling in cultured LX-2 cells. Morin treatment (50 μM) for 24 and 48 h resulted in the decreased levels of Wnt5a/b, Wnt3a, GSK-3β and β-catenin along with G0/G1 specific cell cycle arrest suggesting the inhibition of HSC proliferation bymorin by inhibitingWnt signaling. In addition to the remarkable effects of morin on HSC proliferation and inhibition of Wnt signaling pathway, further investigations to explore its effects on non-canonical signaling pathways are recommended. In DEN induced group, the elevation of β-catenin and its target gene cyclin D1 along with prominent cytosolic and nuclear β-catenin expression warrants the active participation of canonicalWnt pathway. Also, signif- icant downregulation of GSK-3β, β-catenin and its associated proteins bymorin treatment in the protective group and therapeutic group dem- onstrated the anti-fibrotic potential of morin by inhibiting Wnt signal- ing. Hence, the effects of morin shown in this study may provide important insights for the use of morin as a potential integrated medi- cine for the treatment of liver fibrosis. M.B. Rheuben et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 196 (2004) 266–286 285 In summary, the combined evidence of this study and the data published previously suggests that regulated quantal release, and possibly constitutive release, and the interlinked process of recycling of the associated synaptic vesicle membrane, are ultimately targets of DTB toxicity at the onset of muscle weakness. At the present time, we cannot say whether the steps that lead to defects in release or recycling arise first within the terminal or if they are a result of some other process. Sahenk (1990) noticed abnormalities in the intramuscular axons, and it is possible, for example, that axonal transport of new synaptic vesicles is disturbed, leading to a gradually declining population of useable vesicles. Although the terminal Schwann cells do change dramatically, and their participation in this process should not be excluded, the structural changes are not supportive of the idea that they contribute substantially to the physiolog- ical findings at the onset of muscle weakness. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, utilizing multi-parameter testing in human cardiomyocytes in the pre-clinical arenawould assist in lead compound selection and the development of cleaner, safer drugs with improved efficacy for cancer treatment and decreased risk of cardiac damage. As a community, we should strive for drugs like erlotinib, which showed minimal cardiotoxicity across all tests in our screen that improve patient outcome but do not add an additional risk of cardiac adverse events. The ability to thoroughly screen a library of compounds early in pre-clinical development would allow for the selection of those that have minimal cardiotoxicity or are perhaps even cardioprotective to be moved forward into clinical trials. Thus, earlier identification of pos- sible deleterious effects on the heart would likely improve drug candi- date success in clinical trials and offer patients safer therapies. Conflict of interest statement Dr. Brown is a majority owner of ChanTest Corp. Dr. Brown and Dr. Kramer report that Quintiles paid ChanTest Corp. for the ion channel electrophysiology studies performed in support of this paper. Appendix A. content.Acknowledgement: Overall, the results obtained from this study have demonstrated that MWCNT exposure induces changes in lung cancer biomarker gene expression in mouse lungs, which may indicate a potential association between MWCNT exposure-induced lung inflammatory, damage and fibrotic responses and lung carcinogenesis. The results of the IPA also indicate that MWCNT exposure may induce alterations in several disease-related signaling transduction pathways. In light of this finding, long term inhalation studies of MWCNT to monitor possible induction of lung tumors and/or mesothelioma are justified. NIOSH is currently conducting a two week inhalation exposure to MWCNT in a cancer susceptible mouse strain with histological evaluation through 1 year post-exposure to address this issue. Additionally, the results obtained from this study indicate these gene signature alterations of MWCNT exposure and could conceivably be used for the medical surveillance of occupationally-exposed MWCNT workers. Acknowledgments We thank Rebecca Raese for her help in editing the manuscript. This study is supported by NIH/NLMR01LM009500 (PI: Guo) and NCRRP20RR16440 and Supplement (PD: Guo). content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, our study has provided the first evidence to support thatMATE transporters are involved in cellular transport and detoxifica- tion of Cd2+. SinceMATE transporters are highly polymorphic in human populations and their function is important in the disposition of xenobi- otics including clinically used drugs, our findings will be of significance for the identification of factors that influence individual susceptibility to Cd toxicity and the interaction among drugs, environmental toxins and other xenobiotics. In conclusion, the present study suggests that the flavonoid naringin has a renal protective potential. The nephroprotective effect of naringin against gentamicin-induced renal toxicity may be ascribed to its anti-oxidant, anti-apoptosis and anti-inflammatory properties. Collectively, our results suggest that naringin may be a promising molecule for the treatment of gentamicin-induced nephrotoxicity. Therefore, the findings of the present study suggest that exposure to chronic SM produced a state of oxidative stress, resulting, either from the formation of toxic reactive oxygen species because of the impaired mitochondrial bioenergetics or depletion of cellular anti- oxidants such as MnSOD, glutathione reductase and glutathione peroxidase which was instrumental in the release of cytochrome c from mitochondria and its subsequent redistribution into cytosol and activation of caspase-3, upregulation of pro-apoptotic protein Bax, downregulation of anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2 and accumulation of p53 which may target the mitochondrial pathway for inducing apoptosis in response to DNA damage signals following chronic SM exposure in mice brain. Further, it can be reasonably argued that generation of oxidative stress and neuronal apoptotic cell death might constitute the intervening biochemical steps between chronic exposure to SM and appearance of various neurobehavioral deficits. More research in this area is needed to gain a better understanding of the consequences and mechanisms associated with chronic sulphur mustard exposure by employing various antioxidants and inhibitors of caspases to observe any amelioration in sulphur mustard mediated neurotoxicity. The manner with which regional events are communicated from the perivascular zone to neurons requires additional investigation. Cancer cells frequently overexpress HIF-1α and display upregulated expression of hypoxia-responsive genes (Wilson and Hay, 2011; Zhong et al., 1999). Growth arrest-promoting effects of HIF-1α mediated via induction of CDK inhibitors or other mechanisms are not compatible with uncontrolled proliferation of cancer cells. Therefore, it appears that transformed cells evolved to suppress the growth-inhibitory com- ponent of HIF-1α-mediated signalingwhile retaining beneficial proper- ties of hypoxic metabolism (high glucose uptake, for example). This selective loss of HIF-1α functions in cancer helps explain why the ab- sence of HIF-1α had no effect on Ni cytotoxicity in H460 and A549 car- cinoma cells but suppressed Ni-induced cytotoxicity and senescence in normal human cells. Although HIF-1α is frequently described as an on- cogene due to its promotion of many cancer characteristics (Wilson and Hay, 2011), this classification may be appropriate only for advanced stages of cell transformation. In renal cell carcinoma that are caused by the inactivation of the HIF-1α/HIF-2α E3 ubiquitin ligase VHL, ex- pression of HIF-1α is almost always lost and it is viewed as a tumor sup- pressor (Shen and Kaelin, 2013). Our findings in normal cells suggest that in the early phase of Ni carcinogenesis, HIF-1α may also operate in a tumor suppressor-like manner acting to restrict proliferation of se- verely damaged cells. A.P. Pineda-Zavaleta et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 198 (2004) 283–290 289 both PbB and AsU. Superoxide production in directly activated monocytes was negatively associated with AsU but positively associated with PbB. The models including the interaction term for AsU and PbB suggested the possi- bility of a negative interaction for NO production and a positive interaction for superoxide. These effects may pro- vide an explanation for some of the abnormalities of the immune system functioning associated with an increased incidence of infectious disease, cancer and/or aberrant humoral immunity in exposed human populations. Further studies in larger populations are required to characterize and understand the interactions between As and Pb and the mechanism(s) underlying the observed effects. content.CoiStatement: 216 A. Cockburn et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 270 (2013) 209–217 can overwhelm the normal the process of anabolism to ammonia, resulting in the potential for significant systemic exposure to nitrite and MetHb formation. NOAELs for nitrite intake for pigs and cows have been estimated from the literature at approximately 3.3 mg/kg b.w. per day for both species. The total nitrite intake for pigs and cattle consuming complete feed containing nitrite at the maximum limit under EU legislation was found to be 9-fold and 5-fold lower than the NOAEL. Based on the bulkiness of animal feed this represents a satisfactory margin of safety to protect animal health and welfare. Despite the very limited quantitative information on nitrite residues in fresh animal products the evidence indicates that the potential for accumulation of nitrite in animal tissues is very low. This is due to its rapid metabolic turnover and excretion. Separate calculations, based on dietary surveys conducted in EU Member States, showed that compared with the total daily exposure to nitrite, most of nitrite exposure derives from inter- conversion from nitrate contained in fruit and vegetables, fresh animal products contribute a maximum of 2.9% of the total daily exposure to nitrite. It is concluded that such a contribution of nitrite from animal products does not raise any concern for human health. Conflict of interest No competing interests between the authors were identified. content.CoiStatement: ↓ Testes (35%) ↓ PLT (marked) ↓ RETIC, % RETIC (mode ↓ LYMPH, LYMPH% (mo (−)-JQ1 inactive 25 75 ↓ Testes (23%) ↓ PLT (mild) BET has emerged as a promising therapeutic target in oncology and inhibitors are being evaluated in clinical trials (Filippakopoulos and Knapp, 2014). Patient safety data from clinical trials is consistent with the toxicity findings from the nonclinical studies, and these findings are in turn consistent with the pharmacology of the target. Bone marrow toxicity, in particular thrombocytopenia and neutropenia, appeared to be the dose-limiting toxicities observed in a phase 1 trial with OTX015 (Thieblemont et al., 2014). While these adverse effects are not unexpected given the available nonclinical data generated in vitro and in vivo with various BET inhibitors, it does suggest the probable lack of a sufficient therapeutic index for BET inhibitors for non-oncology disease indications. The 30 mg/kg BID oral dose level of JQ1 has been shown to be efficacious in mouse models of anti- inflammation for immunology and atherosclerosis formetabolic disease (internal observations, data not shown). However, although this dose was tolerated, it was also associated with toxic effects on lymphocytes in the thymus and spleen and corresponding hematology changes. Overall our findings reveal that BET inhibition affects the lymphoid and hematopoietic tissue compartments in the mouse, indicating that there are very narrow safety margins. As the medicinal chemistry research for BET inhibitors expands and better selectivity and potency are gained, it will be interesting to determine if a selective inhibitor for BRD2 would have a better safety profile compared to BRD4 or vice- versa for a non-oncology indication. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, by using mice with genetically altered Nrf2 activity, the current study demonstrates that Nrf2 does not prevent the devel- opment of obesity induced by a Western HFD in mice, nor directly regulates fatty acid metabolism in liver. Nrf2 deficiency improves glu- cose tolerance in mice fed a HFD, whereas Nrf2 activation worsens glucose tolerance in mice fed either a control diet or a HFD. The effect of Nrf2 on glucose homeostasis appears to be mediated by its negative regulation of the anti-diabetic hormone Fgf21 in liver, as well as its ef- fects on cell metabolism pathways that interact with reactive oxygen species. In this study, we used Nrf2−/− mice to demonstrate that Nrf2 is able to alleviate damage in response to arsenic exposure. Arsenic appeared to bemore toxic to Nrf2−/−mice compared to Nrf2+/+mice, as measured by physiological changes, DNA methylation, oxidative DNA damage, and apoptotic cell death. Arsenic caused detectable physiologic alterations, especially in the liver and bladder in both Nrf2 +/+ and Nrf2−/− mice. Although skin damage is frequently observed in the arsenic-exposed population, we did not observe any skin lesions during the course of our study. Two rational reasons can be envisioned: (1) in addition to exposure through drinking water, human exposure to arsenic also includes direct contact with the skin; however, in our study arsenic was solely administered through the digestive system, and (2) the duration of arsenic exposure was not long enough to induce skin damage. More importantly, these results indicate a protective role of Nrf2 against arsenic toxicity in vivo. Therefore, we believe that specific activation of the ARE–Nrf2–Keap1 pathway by a reagent with low toxicity should be a great strategy to combat arsenic-induced damage. Our findings will lay the ground- work for dietary and therapeutic interventions against arsenic adverse effects. content.CoiStatement: In summary, the present study investigated the effects of pretreat- ment with FXR agonist OCA on CCl4-induced acute liver injury and he- patic inflammation. Our results showed that pretreatment with OCA protected mice from CCl4-induced hepatocyte apoptosis and necrosis. We found that pretreatment with OCA down-regulated hepatic inflam- matory chemokine and pro-inflammatory cytokines but up-regulated hepatic anti-inflammatory cytokines during CCl4-induced acute liver in- jury. We demonstrated that pretreatment with OCA, which activated hepatic FXR signaling, simultaneously inhibited CCl4-induced activation of hepatic inflammatory signaling. Our results provide evidence for roles of FXR as an important regulator of hepatic inflammation during toxin-induced acute liver injury. Thus, synthetic FXR agonists including OCA are effective antidotes for hepatic inflammation during acute liver injury. content.Funding: Although there are no preclinical studies of AUY922 ongoing, future studies are warranted to investigate deeply the underlying functional mechanism of the ocular toxicity of HSP90 inhibitors. Future studies are also warranted in immune compromised animals as HSP90 inhibitors are given to cancer patients where the immune system is already emaci- ated. Alternative approaches e.g. global gene expression analysis, quanti- tative metabolite (including neurotransmitter and lipids) and proteomic profiling of the retina, or more sophisticated techniques like high spatial resolution quantitative imaging analysis based on mass spectrometry might provide additional mechanistic insights (Anderson et al., 2014; Magharious et al., 2011; Tan et al., 2016). Funding These studies were sponsored by Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corporation. 4. Discussion Funding Conflict of interest Transparency document Acknowledgments Appendix A. Supplementary data References

content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, protection against enhanced liver injury conferred by OFC is likely due to both direct effects on the microbiome, as well indi- rect effects on hepatic sensitization. These findings are in-line with previous work, in which OFC supplementation was shown to protect against direct effects of HFD on the gutmicrobiome and barrier function (Cani et al., 2007). Prebiotics favor an environment inwhich commensal bacteria can thrive, in lieu of direct delivery of commensal bacteria (i.e., probiotics). As such, this approach may yield more predictable and stable results. Nevertheless, these results serve proof-of-principle that protecting against microbiome changes caused by arsenic can prevent the enhancement of inflammatory liver injury caused by this environmental contaminant. LR transporting Oatps/OATPs explains well the preferential organ toxicity of microcystins in liver and brain. Thus, Oatp1b2, OATP1B1, and OATP1B3 are responsible for uptake of microcystin-LR into rat and human hepatocytes, respectively, while OATP1A2 mediates microcystin-LR transport across the blood–brain barrier. The reduced microcystin-LR toxicity in Oatp/OATP-expressing oocytes co-incubated with BSP and TC indicates that administration of high affinity co-substrates of OATP1B1, OATP1B3, and OATP1A2 could provide a therapeutic option to reduce liver damage or neurotoxicity in microcystin-intoxicated patients. In conclusion, the present results showing inhibition of DES formation by OPT pesticides have pointed out that the potential drug–toxicant interaction may be of physiological, pharmacological, and toxicological relevance, especially in the presence of prolonged exposure. The eventual clinical consequences should be considered in different groups of individuals, in order to avoid inefficient therapy and/or undesirable side effects. This approach considering a drug– toxicant interactions in specific exposure scenarios may represent an important future issue to be considered in the safety evaluation of new drug candidates. Acknowledgments This work has been partially supported by the ISS Discussion Acknowledgment References

In summary, there was a consistent indication that sperm chromatin alterations were associated to OP exposure. Thus, we suggest that sperm chromatin structure, as reflected by its sensitivity to in situ denaturation, is a target for OP exposure and a valuable parameter to be included in the study of reproductive toxicants. content.Compliance with ethical standards: BPD is triggered by volutrauma, barotrauma, and hyperoxia during mechanical ventilation and is exacerbated by other stressors, including infection, inflammation, and pulmonary volume overload. However, based on studies in ventilated animals in which these insults have been analyzed individually, it appears that hyperoxia is the most important trigger of pathologic changes associated with BPD and that high levels of inspired oxygen potentiate injury induced by volume and pres- sure during ventilation of the premature neonatal lung (Delemos et al., 1987; Davis et al., 1991). Consistent with this idea is the observation that exposure of neonatal mice to 85% oxygen for 28 days resulted in decreased lung cell prolifera- tion, an accumulation of inflammatory cells in the tissue, and increased pulmonary interleukin (IL)-1� and macrophage in- flammatory protein-1� production. This is associated with de- creased lung volume and compliance and a pathologic lesion very similar to BPD (Warner et al., 1998). Similarly, Han et al. (1996) reported that exposure of neonatal rats to 60% oxygen for 2 weeks resulted in lesions resembling BPD. Interestingly, exposure to higher levels of inspired oxygen resulted in exces- sive toxicity and arrest of lung cell DNA synthesis rather than BPD-like changes. This suggests that there is a limited range of oxygen concentrations that can trigger BPD, even in the pres- ence of less than maximal support, consistent with the new epidemiology of BPD. A role for oxygen in BPD is also supported by the finding that morphologic changes in the lung associated with BPD are mitigated by agents that reduce oxi- dative injury (superoxide dismutase and catalase) (Wilborn et al., 1996). Recent investigations have focused on elucidating cellular and physiologic mechanisms that mediate oxygen- induced edema and fibrosis. Several potential mechanisms have been identified: dysregulated inflammation, altered pro- tease/antiprotease balance, and/or altered growth and differen- tiation of lung cells. Dysregulated inflammation. Prolonged exposure to in- haled oxygen is characterized by rapid neutrophil infiltration into the lung. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) neutrophil counts

content.CoiStatement: Collectively, our findings in the present study suggested that PTP1B may play a contributory role in liver fibrosis. To our knowledge, this Fig. 8. Overview of PTP research may be the first report involved in the expression and role of PTP1B in liver fibrosis. In this study, blockade of PTP1B inhibits TGF-β- induced HShuang-Peng Cai-T6 cell activation and proliferation, while over- expression of PTP1B hinders the inactivation of HShuang-Peng Cai-T6 cells (Fig. 8). These results indicate the potential of PTP1B as a therapeutic target for liver fibrosis. Pharmacological agents that inhibit PTP1Bmight be a per- spective regarding treatment of liver fibrosis. Therefore, designing and developing PTP1B inhibitors with extremely high potency and selectiv- ity and directing the agents to the location of interest are of great signif- icance for remedying fibrosis. Nevertheless, the fundamental mechanism of PTP1B in the setting of liver fibrosis thus far is incom- pletely understood. Next, studies applied in vitro and in vivo techniques will be conducted urgently to explore the mechanism, especially the substrates and signaling pathways that are regulated by PTP1B. Looking to the future, we will have a better picture of the complex function and mechanism of PTP1B in liver fibrosis, which could be of great signifi- cance in predicting the pace of disease progression and developing the targeted therapeutic medicines. 377G. Giordano et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 256 (2011) 369–378 inmitochondriawould support a role for this enzyme in protecting cells from oxidative damage. A recent study in HeLa cells has shown that PON2 binds to Coenzyme Q10 that associates with complex III in mitochondria, and that PON2 deficiency causes mitochondrial dysfunc- tion (Devarajan et al., 2011). Furthermore, in human endothelial cells, PON2 has been shown to reduce, indirectly, but specifically, the release of superoxide from the inner mitochondrial membrane, without affecting levels of other radicals such as H2O2 and peroxynitrite (Altenhofer et al., 2010). Interestingly, the Cys311Ser mutation that influences lactonase activity (Stoltz et al., 2009) does not appear to affect PON2's antioxidantproperties, suggesting independenthydrolytic and anti-oxidant functions (Altenhofer et al., 2010). Xu et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 195 (2004) 232–246 245 possible that POH may not be useful as a single agent but could be effective as an adjuvant therapy and may aid in sensitizing cells to apoptosis. Thus, future clinical trials with this agent should focus on determining the effectiveness of combination therapy protocols in the treatment of lung tumors. If POH can sensitize cells to DNA damage by stimulating caspase-3 activity, the use of a combination of drugs may yield a more effective chemotherapeutic effect at doses of drugs better tolerated by patients. demonstrate that chronic, low-level MMAIII-induced ROS have the capacity to cause genotoxic insult. Following chronic, low-level MMAIII exposure in URO-MSC cells, DNA damage in the presence of MMAIII is significantly elevated after 12 weeks and remains elevated through 52 weeks. Upon removal of MMAIII for 2 weeks, DNA damage levels in URO-MSC cells remain elevated and increase in a time- dependent manner when compared to control UROtsa despite the absence of MMAIII. Yamauchi et al. (2004) demonstrated that the length of inorganic arsenic exposure dictates the ability of individuals to recover from oxidative DNA damage. In the URO-MSC(−) cells following previous chronic, low-level exposure DNA damage levels remain elevated, possibly due to an increase in the length of time necessary to recover. The decreased levels of PARP activity in the presence of MMAIII may also explain the significantly elevated levels of DNA damage first occurring at 12 weeks in the presence of 50 nM MMAIII. When MMAIII is removed for 2 weeks, a time-dependent increase in PARP activity may account for the decrease in DNA damage levels in URO-MSC(−) cells out of MMAIII exposure. Taken together, the increased DNA damage as a result of MMAIII-induced ROS in concert with an overall decrease in repair capacity in the presence of MMAIII may play a key role in generating an indirect genotoxic insult and an overall contribution in the progression of arsenic-induced bladder carcinogenesis. Coexposure at a high dose (60/60 mg/kg) modified the blood kinetics of both parent compounds and is most likely associated with competition between CPF and DZN for CYP450 metabolism, although modifications in oral bioavailability cannot be excluded. However, at lower doses, most likely to be encountered in both occupational- and environmental-related exposures, the pharmacokinetics are expected to be linear. A dose-dependent inhibition of ChE activity was also noted in plasma, RBC, and brain for both the single and coexposures to CPF and DZN. In all tissues, the overall potency for ChE inhibition was greater for CPF than DZN and the binary mixture response appeared to be strongly influenced by CPF at all doses. A comparison of the ChE response at the low dose (15 mg/ kg) where there are no pharmacokinetic interactions for the binary mixture suggests that the overall ChE response is additive. These experiments provide needed insight for evaluating interactions for binary pesticide mixtures and can be used for assessing the potential cumulative risk associated with occupational or environmental exposures to these insecticides. Acknowledgments This publication was partially supported by grant 5 R01 Discussion Acknowledgments References

In conclusion, pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic interactions of morin and CsA are both important determi- nants for the in vivo consequence. 135J.W. Fisher et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 257 (2011) 122–136 aggregate U.S. exposure. The claim by Taylor et al. (2011) that 2 ng/ml (8.8 nM) of aglycone BPA in systemic circulation is common in humans is not supported by the findings of Teeguarden et al. (2011) or by this human PBPK model for BPA. An oral bolus BPA dose of 686 μg/kg of BPA (48,000 μg BPA for a 70 kg person) would be required to obtain peak serum levels of aglycone BPA near 2 ng/ml because of extensive presystemic metabolism. Given the short systemic half life of BPA be- cause of its rapid metabolism, the upper bound aggregate intake of BPA (≤1 μg/kg bw/d; (Calafat et al., 2008; LaKind and Naiman, 2011) and difficulty in reaching a quasi-steady state condition, aglycone BPA serum concentrations of 2 ng/ml appear very unlikely. Given this infor- mation, measured levels of aglycone native BPA in serum of humans mentioned by Taylor et al. (2011) are more plausibly understood as the result of sample contamination, a challenge for every laboratory conducting analyses of BPA samples (Twaddle et al., 2010). The use of non-compartmental pharmacokinetic parameters (NCPPs) to characterize the kinetic data for BPA and its metabolites (e.g., maxi- mum serum concentration or area-under-the-concentration-curve (AUC) for serum) have been used to extrapolate across dose and species. Because of extensive presystemic metabolism of BPA, linearity in NCPPs are apparent for orally administer BPA in several species. The use of this simple methodology for extrapolation across both species and dose is a first-approximation and should be interpreted with care. For example, without capturing the oral uptake phase of systemic aglycone BPA, deter- mining the likely maximum concentration of BPA or the likely AUC for aglycone BPA is difficult. A major portion of the AUC valuemay be repre- sented by the time interval from time of dosing to the first time point in which a serumBPAmeasurement is taken. The trapezoid rule for integra- tion using routine procedures assumes a straight line from time zero (timeof dosing) to thefirstmeasured timepoint, perhapsmissing impor- tant kinetic information. To compare model-predicted metrics across age and species, a sin- gle bolus dose of BPA (100 μg/kg) was simulated for 24 h in PND 5, 35 and 70 monkeys and in adult monkeys and humans using the cali- brated BPA model. The predicted peak serum level of BPA in the PND 5 monkey was 2 times the BPA concentrations in the older in- fants and adult monkeys, which were similar to each other. The pre- dicted adult human peak BPA serum concentration was somewhat higher (1.3 nM) than the adult monkey (0.87 nM). Significant age- dependent pharmacokinetic behaviors were observed for BPA metab- olites. The peak concentration and AUC values for BPA metabolites declined with age by nearly 2 times and 6 times, respectively, in PND 5 and adult monkeys. The predicted peak concentration and AUC values for BPA metabolites in adult humans were 50% higher and 4 times greater than in adult monkeys. At 24 h after dosing the predicted BPA dose (as BPA metabolites) remaining in the body was 1% in the monkeys, irrespective of age, and 2–4% of the dose (as BPA metabolites) remained in the adult humans. The model-predicted adult monkey dosimetrics, for a given dose per kg BW, is not equivalent to an adult human for the BPA metabolites. However, model-predicted peak serum free BPA levels were similar be- tween adultmonkeys and humans, with free BPA 24 h serumAUC values slightly higher (3.7–4.0 nM/24 h) than adult monkeys (~2.0 nM/24 h). Extrapolation of NCPPs from adult monkeys to adult humans with as- sumptions about linearity will introduce large errors for BPAmetabolites and until aglycone BPA is measured in human serum, the model predic- tions in this paper, based onmonkey BPA kinetic studies, provide the best estimates of aglycone BPA levels in humans. A controlled human intentional BPA dosing study, similar to the Völkel et al. (2002) study, using updated analytical methods, similar to Teeguarden et al. (2011), would provide important information about the serum levels of aglycone BPA. The new human BPA kinetic study could help determine if monkeys and humans process BPA in a similar fashion and provide confidence in the utility of models devel- oped with data obtained in nonhuman primates for human risk assessment. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, after oral administration to rats, opicaponewas rapid- ly absorbed and eliminated, presenting an extent of systemic exposure which was approximately dose-proportional within the studied dose range (30–90 mg/kg). Moreover, the systemic accumulation of opicapone and BIA 9-1079 seemed to be negligible. content.CoiStatement: In summary, the present study demonstrates that the UPR signaling is activated in the pathogenesis of CCl4-induced hepatic fibrosis. PBA, a well-known ER chemical chaperone, inhibits CCl4-induced hepatic ER stress and the UPR signaling. Moreover, PBA alleviates CCl4-induced hepatic NF-κB translocation andMAPK signaling. In addition, PBA atten- uates CCl4-induced inflammatory response and subsequent HSC activa- tion. Importantly, PBA effectively prevents CCl4-induced hepaticfibrosis in mice (Fig. 7). Thus, chemical chaperone may have potential preven- tive and therapeutic utilities for protecting against liver fibrosis. In summary, our studies have shown that sulindac can suppress UVB-induced inflammation and the expression of surrogate makers of phototoxicity and carcinogenesis in murine skin. Topical formulations of COX-2 inhibitors may offer an alternative approach to skin cancer chemo- prevention, with fewer adverse effects as compared to systemic administration of these agents. content.Acknowledgement: Dose-response experiments will be needed, especially in the case of genistein, because it has been observed that it could cause almost similar transient and lasting alterations in the reproductive systems of the male rats at low (5 mg/kg/ day) and high doses (300 mg/kg/day; Wisniewski et al., 2003). Pronounced effects on the reproductive success of the h-sitosterol females were detected in this study and for this reason, it is crucial to investigate the reproductive effects at different doses. Increased probability of repro- duction has been observed earlier in tundra voles (Microtus oeconomus) exposed to phytosterols (5 mg/kg/day; Niemi- nen et al., 2004). Thus, it would be important to examine if the increased reproductive success of the mink is dose- dependent. This effect could be harmful in nature with limited food resources, but it could be of economical use in domestic animal production. The results of this study cannot be directly applied to human risk assessment. Yet further studies are warranted, as chronic exposure to these substances causes signs of endocrine disruption in the mink. Due to the widespread use of phytoestrogens in the treatment of hyperlipidemias and postmenopausal symptoms the potential chronic effects of these compounds to human reproduction cannot be overlooked. Abrogation of p53 transcription activity or mitochondrial targeting reduces mitochondrial damage, oxidative stress and neuronal death under Mn exposure. In summary, we identified stibine and trimethylstibine as two genotoxic forms of antimony that damaged DNA probably by the generation of ROS. No other forms of antimony were genotoxic. Our conclusions were based on assuming that the generation of stibine and trimethylstibine using sodium borohydride is 100% efficient, if this is not the case then we might have underestimated the potency of these antimony compounds. The effect of arsines and stibines on the environment and on human health warrants further consideration. PGE2 production, with selective cyclooxygenase-2 inhib- itors, very effectively blocked jet fuel-induced immune suppression (Ramos et al., 2002; Ullrich and Lyons, 2000). In this study, we targeted an event up-stream of PGE2 production, PAF-receptor binding, and saw similar results. Although the safety of PAF-receptor antagonists in humans is unknown, blocking jet fuel-induced immune suppression with anti-oxidants, such as Vitamins C and E, has the potential to be useful in protecting humans against jet fuel-induced immunotoxicity. Surviving rats of both rat lines showed decreased body weight gain, and the decrease was greater the younger the rats were exposed. No specific differences between Ahr hw and B hw alleles could be detected in terms of body weight gain. A high incidence of hydronephrosis was observed in both rat lines when exposed on D2–D17. This finding indicates that rat urinary tract epithelium is still sensitive to high doses of TCDD after birth, and that rats with Ahr hw or B hw alleles are not resistant to this effect. content.CoiStatement: 41L.-P. Liang et al. / Toxicology and Applied Pharmacology 326 (2017) 34–42 active metabolite, Manisha PatelP+ in the striatum (Giovanni et al., 1991). The levels of Manisha PatelP+ was determined in the striatum 3 h after metalloporphyrin administration to eliminate the possibility that metalloporphyrins interfere with striatal Manisha PatelTP metabolism (Liang et al., 2007). No differenceswere observed in striatalManisha PatelP+ concentrations measured 3 h after a single dose of Manisha PatelTP (15 mg/kg, s.c.) alone or 1 h after 15mg/kg, i.p. dose of AEOL 11207, 11203 or 11114 (Manisha PatelTP± vehi- cle: 14.30± 2.74, (6);Manisha PatelTP±AEOL 11207: 14.95± 1.98, (4);Manisha PatelTP± AEOL 11203: 14.63± 3.36, (4) andManisha PatelTP± AEOL 11114: 14.79± 2.81, (4) μg/g tissue; values are expressed as mean + S.E.M. (N) This data suggests that the protective effects of metalloporphyrins on Manisha PatelTP neu- rotoxicity were not due to altered Manisha PatelTP metabolism and/or bioavailability. 4. Discussion In this study, we identified several metalloporphyrins (AEOL 11203, AEOL 11209, AEOL 11215, AEOL11216 andAEOL 11114)with improved pharmacodynamics profiles. This series of glyoxylatemetalloporphyrins were designed to have greater lipid solubility, oral bioavailability, and ability to cross the BBB (Trova et al., 2003). The results indicate that three of the compounds (AEOL 11203, AEOL 11216 and AEOL 11114) are BBB permeable by the i.p. route and two of them (AEOL 11203 and AEOL 11114) are orally active. The data suggest that AEOL 11203 and AEOL 11114, which are similar to AEOL 11207 (Liang et al., 2007), have relatively long plasma half-lives, rapid absorption by the gastrointestinal tract, ability to penetrate the BBB, and can achieve therapeutically active concentrations in the brain. Our phar- macokinetic data demonstrate a 33% and 30% oral bioavailability (AUCoral/AUCip%) and AUCoral of 9.46 μM/h and 3.10 μM/h in the brain for AEOL 11114 and AEOL 11203, respectively. AEOL 11114 was more effective orally than AEOL 11203 at inhibiting markers of oxidative stress and Manisha PatelTP neurotoxicity in our animal model. This is likely due to the higher oral availability and higher AUC of AEOL 11114 compared to AEOL 11203. Previous data suggest that metalloporphyrins are extremely stable and retain their metal even in the presence of EDTA (Kachadourian et al., 2004). Several of these compounds have been found to be safe and efficacious when used in both in vitro and in vivo models (Day and Crapo, 1996; Patel et al., 1996). In our study, we did not detect alter- ations in manganese levels in brain or neurobehavioral abnormality reminiscent of manganese toxicity following daily dosing of AEOL 11207, AEOL 11114, or AEOL 11203. In contrast, the manganese levels increased ~10 fold accompanied by a significant rotarod deficit in mice treated daily with an equivalent dose of MnCl2. These results indicate that the glyoxylate series of metalloporphyrins lack signs of neurotoxicity and do not result in brain manganese accumulation. AEOL 11114 and AEOL 11203 are highly lipophilic compounds and were dissolved in 5% or 1% DSMO, respectively. No significant change in body weight or behavior was found in the mice with 5% or 1% DSMO vehicle administration, which are the same volumes and doses as AEOL 11114 and AEOL 11203 injection (1 ml/kg/day x3, i.p. or p.o.), comparison with saline controls. Taken together, our data suggests that AEOL 11114 and AEOL 11203 are excellent candidates for clinical therapeutic development of neurological diseases. Manisha PatelTP is a neurotoxicant producing clinical, biochemical, and neuro- pathological changes in both human and experimental animals that are analogous to those observed in idiopathic Parkinson's disease (PD) (Beal, 2001; Przedborski and Vila, 2003). Manisha PatelTP treatment induces sig- nificant DA depletion in the striatum and DA neurons loss in the SNpc of C57BL6 mice which has been considered a well-established mouse model of PD for 30 years (Sonsalla and Heikkila, 1986; Liberatore et al., 1999; Przedborski and Vila, 2003; Liang et al., 2007). The stereolog- ical method we employed to estimate the number of TH-positive cell in SNpc as well as HPLC measurement of DA in the striatum have been shown to be reliable techniques for evaluating dopaminergic system function. This function was found to be protected by metalloporphyrin treatment in the Manisha PatelTP model. One of the major mechanisms of Manisha PatelTP neurotoxicity in vivo is thought to arise from oxidative stress due to superoxide (O2 −•) produc- tion from mitochondrial complex I inhibition and impaired energetics. Manisha PatelTP neurotoxicity is also thought to result in excessive nitric oxide (•NO) production by microglial activation via inflammatory mecha- nisms (Przedborski and Jackson-Lewis, 1998). NO can react with O2 −• to form the highly reactive nitrogen species peroxynitrite (ONOO−), which causes nitration of tyrosine residues forming 3-NT in various pro- teins, including TH and α-synuclein, and results in protein dysfunction (Ara et al., 1998; Blanchard-Fillion et al., 2001). Increased 3-NT is con- sidered an important biomarker of oxidative/nitrative protein damage in Manisha PatelTP-induced Parkinsonism (Przedborski et al., 1996; Pennathur et al., 1999; Wu et al., 2002). The levels of GSH, GSSG and the ratio of this redox couple (GSH/GSSG) serve as a major intracellular indicator of redox status and oxidative stress in cells and tissues (Valko et al., 2007). A depletion of GSH levels has been observed in post-mortem samples from the SN of PD patients and in the ventral midbrain region of Manisha PatelTP-treated rodents (Perry et al., 1982; Bannon et al., 1984; Ferraro et al., 1986; Sian et al., 1994). In fact, GSH depletion is thought to play a primary pathogenic role in the etiology of PD (Jenner et al., 1992). Our results show that a Manisha PatelTP treatment decreased the GSH/ GSSG ratio and increased 3-NT formation, which correlate with the oc- currence of dopamine depletion and dopaminergic cell loss. The ability of metalloporphyrins to attenuate Manisha PatelTP-induced alterations of GSH/ GSSG ratios and 3NT correlates with their antioxidant activities and their Cmax in the brain. For example, AEOL 11203, which has a lower cat- alase activity and Cmax (~50 nM) was less effective against Manisha PatelTP-in- duced oxidative stress and DA depletion compared to AEOL 11114 which has a Cmax of ~230 nM in the brain via the oral route. Better clin- ically relevant oxidative stress biomarkers are needed to bridge pre- clinical animal study results with optimizing safe and efficacious doses in potential PD clinical trials. The data collectively suggest that orally activemetalloporphyrin cat- alytic antioxidants that readily penetrate the BBBmay be potential ther- apeutic agents for chronic neurologic diseases such as PD. Two glyoxylate metalloporphyrins catalytic antioxidants identified in this study (AEOL 11114 and AEOL 11203) and one glyoxylate metalloporphyrin catalytic antioxidant (AEOL 11207) identified in a previous study (Liang et al., 2007) may be potential candidates for fur- ther clinical development therapy for PD. The levels of MPP+ was determined in the striatum 3 h after metalloporphyrin administration to eliminate the possibility that metalloporphyrins interfere with striatal MPTP metabolism (Liang et al., 2007). No differenceswere observed in striatalMPP+ concentrations measured 3 h after a single dose of MPTP (15 mg/kg, s.c.) alone or 1 h after 15mg/kg, i.p. dose of AEOL 11207, 11203 or 11114 (MPTP± vehi- cle: 14.30± 2.74, (6);MPTP±AEOL 11207: 14.95± 1.98, (4);MPTP± AEOL 11203: 14.63± 3.36, (4) andMPTP± AEOL 11114: 14.79± 2.81, (4) μg/g tissue; values are expressed as mean + S.E.M. (N) This data suggests that the protective effects of metalloporphyrins on MPTP neu- rotoxicity were not due to altered MPTP metabolism and/or bioavailability. 4. Discussion In this study, we identified several metalloporphyrins (AEOL 11203, AEOL 11209, AEOL 11215, AEOL11216 andAEOL 11114)with improved pharmacodynamics profiles. This series of glyoxylatemetalloporphyrins were designed to have greater lipid solubility, oral bioavailability, and ability to cross the BBB (Trova et al., 2003). The results indicate that three of the compounds (AEOL 11203, AEOL 11216 and AEOL 11114) are BBB permeable by the i.p. route and two of them (AEOL 11203 and AEOL 11114) are orally active. The data suggest that AEOL 11203 and AEOL 11114, which are similar to AEOL 11207 (Liang et al., 2007), have relatively long plasma half-lives, rapid absorption by the gastrointestinal tract, ability to penetrate the BBB, and can achieve therapeutically active concentrations in the brain. Our phar- macokinetic data demonstrate a 33% and 30% oral bioavailability (AUCoral/AUCip%) and AUCoral of 9.46 μM/h and 3.10 μM/h in the brain for AEOL 11114 and AEOL 11203, respectively. AEOL 11114 was more effective orally than AEOL 11203 at inhibiting markers of oxidative stress and MPTP neurotoxicity in our animal model. This is likely due to the higher oral availability and higher AUC of AEOL 11114 compared to AEOL 11203. Previous data suggest that metalloporphyrins are extremely stable and retain their metal even in the presence of EDTA (Kachadourian et al., 2004). Several of these compounds have been found to be safe and efficacious when used in both in vitro and in vivo models (Day and Crapo, 1996; Patel et al., 1996). In our study, we did not detect alter- ations in manganese levels in brain or neurobehavioral abnormality reminiscent of manganese toxicity following daily dosing of AEOL 11207, AEOL 11114, or AEOL 11203. In contrast, the manganese levels increased ~10 fold accompanied by a significant rotarod deficit in mice treated daily with an equivalent dose of MnCl2. These results indicate that the glyoxylate series of metalloporphyrins lack signs of neurotoxicity and do not result in brain manganese accumulation. AEOL 11114 and AEOL 11203 are highly lipophilic compounds and were dissolved in 5% or 1% DSMO, respectively. No significant change in body weight or behavior was found in the mice with 5% or 1% DSMO vehicle administration, which are the same volumes and doses as AEOL 11114 and AEOL 11203 injection (1 ml/kg/day x3, i.p. or p.o.), comparison with saline controls. Taken together, our data suggests that AEOL 11114 and AEOL 11203 are excellent candidates for clinical therapeutic development of neurological diseases. MPTP is a neurotoxicant producing clinical, biochemical, and neuro- pathological changes in both human and experimental animals that are analogous to those observed in idiopathic Parkinson's disease (PD) (Beal, 2001; Przedborski and Vila, 2003). MPTP treatment induces sig- nificant DA depletion in the striatum and DA neurons loss in the SNpc of C57BL6 mice which has been considered a well-established mouse model of PD for 30 years (Sonsalla and Heikkila, 1986; Liberatore et al., 1999; Przedborski and Vila, 2003; Liang et al., 2007). The stereolog- ical method we employed to estimate the number of TH-positive cell in SNpc as well as HPLC measurement of DA in the striatum have been shown to be reliable techniques for evaluating dopaminergic system function. This function was found to be protected by metalloporphyrin treatment in the MPTP model. One of the major mechanisms of MPTP neurotoxicity in vivo is thought to arise from oxidative stress due to superoxide (O2 −•) produc- tion from mitochondrial complex I inhibition and impaired energetics. MPTP neurotoxicity is also thought to result in excessive nitric oxide (•NO) production by microglial activation via inflammatory mecha- nisms (Przedborski and Jackson-Lewis, 1998). NO can react with O2 −• to form the highly reactive nitrogen species peroxynitrite (ONOO−), which causes nitration of tyrosine residues forming 3-NT in various pro- teins, including TH and α-synuclein, and results in protein dysfunction (Ara et al., 1998; Blanchard-Fillion et al., 2001). Increased 3-NT is con- sidered an important biomarker of oxidative/nitrative protein damage in MPTP-induced Parkinsonism (Przedborski et al., 1996; Pennathur et al., 1999; Wu et al., 2002). The levels of GSH, GSSG and the ratio of this redox couple (GSH/GSSG) serve as a major intracellular indicator of redox status and oxidative stress in cells and tissues (Valko et al., 2007). A depletion of GSH levels has been observed in post-mortem samples from the SN of PD patients and in the ventral midbrain region of MPTP-treated rodents (Perry et al., 1982; Bannon et al., 1984; Ferraro et al., 1986; Sian et al., 1994). In fact, GSH depletion is thought to play a primary pathogenic role in the etiology of PD (Jenner et al., 1992). Our results show that a MPTP treatment decreased the GSH/ GSSG ratio and increased 3-NT formation, which correlate with the oc- currence of dopamine depletion and dopaminergic cell loss. The ability of metalloporphyrins to attenuate MPTP-induced alterations of GSH/ GSSG ratios and 3NT correlates with their antioxidant activities and their Cmax in the brain. For example, AEOL 11203, which has a lower cat- alase activity and Cmax (~50 nM) was less effective against MPTP-in- duced oxidative stress and DA depletion compared to AEOL 11114 which has a Cmax of ~230 nM in the brain via the oral route. Better clin- ically relevant oxidative stress biomarkers are needed to bridge pre- clinical animal study results with optimizing safe and efficacious doses in potential PD clinical trials. The data collectively suggest that orally activemetalloporphyrin cat- alytic antioxidants that readily penetrate the BBBmay be potential ther- apeutic agents for chronic neurologic diseases such as PD. Two glyoxylate metalloporphyrins catalytic antioxidants identified in this study (AEOL 11114 and AEOL 11203) and one glyoxylate metalloporphyrin catalytic antioxidant (AEOL 11207) identified in a previous study (Liang et al., 2007) may be potential candidates for fur- ther clinical development therapy for PD. content.CoiStatement: In conclusion, the present study is the first one to provide evidence that cardamonin has nephroprotective effect against cisplatin-induced renal injury. The mechanisms underlying this nephroprotective effect could be partially through counteracting cisplatin-induced oxidative stress indicated by significant increase in GSH and SOD aswell decrease in lipid peroxidation. Also, cardamonin has shown a powerful anti- inflammatory activity manifested by reducing pro-inflammatory markers; IL-1β, TNF-α, NF-kB, iNOS, ICAM-1 and MCP-1. In addition, cardamonin attenuated cisplatin-induced increase in NOX-1 expres- sion, which was found to play a role in cisplatin-induced renal injury. Fig. 6.A:Cytotoxicity of various concentrations of cisplatin alone or in combinationwith 25 μMc control value using ANOVA followed by Dunnett test as post-hoc test. bp b 0.05: Statistically sig paired t-test. B: Cytotoxicity of various concentrations of cisplatin alone or in combination with pared to the control value using ANOVA followed by Dunnett test as post-hoc test. bp b 0.05: alone using unpaired t-test. C: Cytotoxicity of various concentrations of cisplatin alone or in com when compared to the control value using ANOVA followed by Dunnett test as post-hoc test. b cisplatin alone using unpaired t-test. D: Cytotoxicity of various concentrations of cisplatin alone cally significantwhen compared to the control value using ANOVA followedbyDunnett test as p treated with cisplatin alone using unpaired t-test. Moreover, cardamonin significantly reduced cell death by decreasing caspases-3 activity and Bax/Bcl-2 ratio as well as by increasing the survival factor, EGF. Interestingly, cisplatin cytotoxic activity was signif- icantly enhanced by pre-treatment with subtoxic concentration of cardamonin for 24 h in four different human cancer cell lines; hela, hepG2, PC3 andHCT116 cancer cell lines. Taken together, these findings suggest that cardamonin improves therapeutic index of cisplatin. We do not present this work as a final solution to the mixture problem defined in the context of a QSPeR LFER model relative to the specific structure of the MF. Rather, we present data that clearly demonstrate that if mixture proper- ties are incorporated into a LFER permeability model that is based on molecular descriptors of the penetrant, signifi- cantly improved prediction of kp results. This would increase estimation of the internal dose in many risk assessment scenarios. This finding has numerous implica- tions to occupational and environmental risk assessment for topical chemical exposure where the predominant exposure scenario is to complex mixtures. content.CoiStatement: In summary, we first confirmed that the reproductive and develop- mental toxicities and the neuroendocrine metabolic programming alteration by prenatal caffeine ingestion have transgenerational effects in rats, which were characterized partially with gender and parental differences. Here, we propose the hypothesis (Fig. 7) that, prenatal caffeine ingestion induces the fetal over-exposure to maternal GC, which may cause the epigenetic alteration of HPA axis functional development-related genes and the GC-dependent changes of blood glucose and lipid metabolic phenotypes in utero (Xu et al., 2012b). This neuroendocrine metabolic programming alteration by caffeine (showing lower basic activity but enhanced stress sensitivity of HPA axis as well as the corresponding alterations of blood glucose and lipid phenotypes) could extend until after birth in F1 (Xu et al., 2012a) and also appeared in F2 rats. This study will be beneficial for elucidating the susceptibility to metabolic syndrome and associated diseases in F2. content.CoiStatement: In summary, we show that prenatal exposure to 5 ppmMeHg results in deficits in neurite outgrowth and synaptic protein expression in the developing rat cerebellum. These abnormalities may be due to MeHg- induced suppression of the TrkA pathway during the prenatal period and subsequent reductions in eEF1A1 expression. content.CoiStatement: At the time there is enough evidence that supports lead as ototoxic agent in humans (Carlson et al., 2018; Hemmativaghef, 2020. One study in adults exposed to lead without noise exposure (>85 dB), showed an increased hearing threshold at high frequencies (>3 kHz), as well as further peripheral and central auditory dysfunction (Castellanos and Fuente, 2016). Another study in children exposed to lead due to elec- tronic waste (e-waste) showed an increased hearing threshold at low frequencies (<2 kHz), even though the children showed low BPb levels (<5 μg/dL) (Liu et al., 2018). These results support that safe limit for lead should be discuss in order to prevent hearing impairment, Hem- mativaghef, 2020 based on significative association studies conclude that a BPb >2 μg/dL is the Lowest Observed Adverse Effect Level (LOAEL) for hearing damage. In our study participants were asked about occupational and leisure noise activities. We observed in audiograms that participants showed a notch related with noise exposure. Actually, noise exposure is a public health problem. Global Burden of Disease 2010 estimated that 1⋅3 billion people are affected by hearing loss and investigators rated hearing loss as the 13th most important contributor (19⋅9 million years, 2⋅6% of total number) to the global years lived with disability (YLD) (Vos and Flxman, 2012). Hearing impairment due to noise exposure could affect by a one-time exposure to an intense impulse sound, or by steady state long-term exposure. Thus, the results that we observed in our participants could be related to noise and lead exposure through life history. The characteristic pathological feature of noise-induced hearing loss is the loss of auditory sensory cells in the cochlea. Because these hair cells cannot regenerate in mammals, no remission can occur; prevention of noise-induced hearing loss is the only option to preserve hearing (Basner et al., 2014). At the molecular level lead is a mimetic for calcium in different cells and tissues (Marchetti, 2013). In the inner ear, the otoconia are the main calcium deposits for the auditory system. Otolin-1 protein plays an important role in storing calcium ions at the basilar and tectorial membranes in the cochlea (Yang et al., 2011). New evidence suggests that the outer hair cells response decreases when calcium stores are altered by exposure noise or calcium chelators (Strimbu et al., 2019). At the time there is no evidence that otolin-1 is affected by noise or calcium chelator exposures. Even though we observed a nonsignificant trend of a decrease in otolin-1 levels by BPb and increased hearing threshold, more studies are needed to evaluate whether otolin-1 levels could be affected by lead exposure. The motor protein prestin increases the length of the outer hair cells to improve sound discrimination and hearing response acting incochlear amplification. Bioinformatic studies suggest that prestin is functionally regulated by calcium/calmodulin (CaM) binding sites, and the CaM- prestin interaction may be involved in the modulation of cochlear amplification (Keller et al., 2014). Hearing loss is a multifactorial and age-specific disease, and lifestyle habits, health status, ototoxicity and noise exposure are important risk factors (Aghazadeh-Attari et al., 2017). The participants in the present study showed a chronic exposure to lead due to work or LGC habits over years, as we showed in multiple regression analysis. We observed that women over 39 years old without MSR and low BPb levels showed the highest serum prestin concentration. Some studies suggest that hearing function in women after menopause is diminished due to the decrease in estrogen levels (Hederstierna et al., 2007). One study evaluated prestin expression in ovariectomized rats and reported a decrease in the amount of prestin RNA, which correlated with an increase in hearing threshold (Diao et al., 2019). In addition to the evidence that the lack of estrogens is related to hearing loss, the presence of MSR plays an important role in hearing capacity as it modifies the composition of the inner ear membrane system (Aghaza- deh-Attari et al., 2017). Similarly, there is evidence that chronic expo- sure to lead can increase the MSR (Planchart et al., 2018). Our study has some limitations that should be considered. The cross- sectional design does not allow us to establish causation for our results. Patella X-ray measurement is the main biomarker for chronic exposure to lead. In our study, we used the BPb as a biomarker because it is a more accessible measure. As we could not measure noise exposure for each participant, we asked them about noise exposure habits, as shown in Table 2. For further studies related to hearing biomarkers and ototox- icity, noise exposure should be measured individually considered as an important control variable. 5. Conclusion This is the first study to evaluate prestin as a potential biomarker for hearing loss due to lead exposure. We concluded that the serum protein prestin concentration decreases according to hearing threshold related to lead exposure. We observed that lead exposure plays an important role in hearing threshold aside environmental noise exposure, in future studies should be considered as an important variable. The molecular bases of hearing impairment, such as overexposure to ototoxic agents, are similarly poorly understood and an area of active research. Juárez-Pérez and Guadalupe Aguilar-Madrid performed the hearing and clinical evaluations to the participants, su- pervised all statistical and epidemiologic models and contributed to the discussion; and Luz M.
